tutorial.title: Quiz App
tutorial.descriptionContent: Create a simple quiz app using a DOM tree and DOM manipulation

executableContent.instructions:
In this project, we will build an HTML quiz page from a DOM tree and then manipulate the quiz page using JavaScript.

Look at the DOM tree example below. We'll build our quiz page using this DOM tree. 

We've already written some starter code. Take a look at the description below to see what's already there.

![html tree]( https://mimo.app/i/dom_tree_quiz.png)


1. In `index.html`, there's the basic HTML skeleton that has `html`, `body` and `script` elements.
2. In `style.css`, we've assigned style properties for all the elements beforehand.
3. In `script.js`, we've written some starting code as well. Here's the description:
    - There's a variable defined as `correctAns` that'll store the correct answer for the respective questions of the quiz.
    - There are two functions : `onSubmit` and `onNext`. `onSubmit` will trigger on clicking the `Submit` button and `onNext` will trigger on clicking the `Next` button.
    - Inside `onSubmit`, we've written the code to get the value of the input box ( `ans` ) and the second paragraph element that we'll add later on.

executableContent.instructions:
![html tree]( https://mimo.app/i/dom_tree_quiz.png)

1. Create the `p` and `input` nodes of the div node. The `p` element should be above the `input` element. This is because the `p` element will display the question and the `input` element will take the answer from the user. Hence, we're asking the question before requiring user input.
2. For the `input` element, set the following attributes:
    - Set `type` to `number`.
    - Set `placeholder` to `Enter the answer`.
    - Set `id` to `answer`.
3. For the `p` element, set the text to:
```
If you multiply this number by any other number, the answer will always be the same. What number is this?
```

executableContent.instructions:
Well done! You've created an HTML page using the DOM tree.

Now, all that's left is to manipulate the DOM so that we can make our quiz app work!

We already have the value of the input box, which is the answer that the user will give. For the first question, the correct answer is 0. 

So we'll use conditionals to check if the user has given the correct answer or not.

1. Code an `if-else` statement inside `onSubmit` function that checks if `ans` equals `correctAns`. If true, then change the `innerHTML` of `resultP` to `"Correct"`, else change it to `"Wrong"`.

hints.title: Hint

executableContent.instructions:
The code for `onSubmit` function is done!

Now, it's time for `onNext` function. When the user clicks the `Next` button, the question, answer etc. should change. 

Let's get started on the question first.

1. Inside the `onNext()` function, get the `input` element using `children` and `firstElementChild` and store it in a variable named `ques`. We must get the body's second child (`div` ). Then get the `div` element's first element child (`input` ).
2. Change the value of the `correctAns` to 1 inside the `onNext` function. This is because the correct answer to the second question is 1.
3. Change the `innerHTML` of `ques` to: 
```
What single digit appears most frequently between and including the numbers 1 and 1,000? Hint: look for a pattern!
```

executableContent.instructions:
Great work, you've just updated the quiz question! 

However, the input box still contains the previous value. 

Let's change that by clearing the input box when the user clicks the `Next` button.

1. Get the input element using `nextElementSibling` and store it in a variable named `inputBox`.
2. Change the value attribute of the input to `""`. This sets the element back to a blank input box.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. You can get the input box using `ques.nextElementSibling` since the input is right below the question paragraph.
2. To change the attribute values of elements, you can use the following syntax: `element.attributeName = new value;`.

executableContent.instructions:
Since we have only two questions, we'll change the `Next` button's text to `End`. This indicates that the user has reached the last quiz question.

1. Get the `Next` button starting from the `inputBox` using `nextElementSibling`. Store it in a variable named `nextButton`.
2. Change the text of the button from `Next` to `End`.

executableContent.instructions:
So now what happens when the user clicks on the `End` button? 

The options are endless! But for the moment, we'll just leave a `This page is for construction!` sign.

Let's code this.

1. Use  the `onclick` property on the `nextButton` and assign an empty arrow function to it.
2. Inside the arrow function, change the body's text to `"This page is under construction!"`.
